prompt: Examine attachment theory from infancy to adulthood, comparing attachment styles, measurement methods, and implications for relationships and mental health.

criteria.name: Theory and Styles
criteria.description: Explains secure, avoidant, ambivalent/resistant, and disorganized attachment.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Accurately defines styles, developmental origins, and behavioral patterns across stages of life.

criteria.name: Assessment Methods
criteria.description: Describes Strange Situation, Adult Attachment Interview, and self-report measures.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Explains procedures, scoring, reliability/validity, and cross-cultural issues.

criteria.name: Implications and Outcomes
criteria.description: Links attachment to relationship patterns and mental health.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Connects styles to intimacy, conflict patterns, emotion regulation, and risk for psychopathology with nuance.
performance_descriptors.good: Reasonable links to outcomes with some depth.

performance_descriptors.excellent: Evaluates stability across lifespan, role of environment, culture, and measurement controversies.
performance_descriptors.good: Notes several critiques with some evaluation.

key_points: Define styles and typical behaviors in infancy and adult relationships.
Explain Strange Situation and Adult Attachment Interview with reliability/validity points.
Discuss links with emotion regulation, conflict styles, and psychopathology risk.
Address cultural variation and stability over time.
Note clinical and relational implications (e.g., therapy focus).
llm_questions: Summarize attachment styles with real-life examples.
How does the Strange Situation classify attachment?
What are adult attachment dimensions in self-report models?
How does attachment style influence conflict resolution?
What is known about attachment stability across the lifespan?
